Definition: The mental faculty of knowing, which includes perceiving, recognizing, conceiving, judging, reasoning, and imagining.
Adapted From: The mental faculty of knowing, which includes perceiving, recognizing, conceiving, judging, reasoning, and imagining.
Citation: cognition. (n.d.). The American Heritage® Stedman's Medical Dictionary. Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=cognition&x=0&y=0

Definition: The concentration of the mind on a single object or thought, especially one preferentially selected from a complex, with a view to limiting or clarifying receptivity by narrowing the range of stimuli.
Adapted From: A concentration of the mind on a single object or thought, especially one preferentially selected from a complex, with a view to limiting or clarifying receptivity by narrowing the range of stimuli.
Citation: attention. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=attention&x=0&y=0

Definition: The mental faculty associated with a body of words and the systems for their use common to a people who are of the same community or nation, the same geographical area, or the same cultural tradition.
Adapted From: A body of words and the systems for their use common to a people who are of the same community or nation, the same geographical area, or the same cultural tradition.
Citation: language. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=language&x=0&y=0

Definition: The study of writing words in language with the proper letters, according to accepted usage and correct spelling.
Adapted From: The art of writing words with the proper letters, according to accepted usage
Citation: correct spelling.
column5: orthography. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=orthography&x=0&y=0

Definition: The study of the distribution and patterning of speech sounds in a language and of the tacit rules governing pronunciation.
Adapted From: The study of the distribution and patterning of speech sounds in a language and of the tacit rules governing pronunciation.
Citation: phonology. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=phonology&x=0&y=0

Definition: The study of meaning in language.
Adapted From: The study or science of meaning in language.
Citation: semantics. (n.d.). The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, Fourth Edition. Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=semantics&x=0&y=0

Definition: The study of expressing or describing thoughts, feelings, or perceptions in language, using words.
Adapted From: The faculty or act of expressing or describing thoughts, feelings, or perceptions by the articulation of words.
Citation: speech. (n.d.). The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, Fourth Edition. Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=speech&x=0&y=0

Definition: The study of the rules for the formation of grammatical sentences in language.
Adapted From: The study of the rules for the formation of grammatical sentences in a language.
Citation: syntax. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=syntax&x=0&y=0

Definition: The mental faculty of retaining and reviving facts, events, or impressions, or of recalling or recognizing previous experiences.
Adapted From: The mental capacity or faculty of retaining and reviving facts, events, impressions, etc., or of recalling or recognizing previous experiences.
Citation: memory. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=memory&x=0&y=0

Definition: The memory for intermediate results that must be held during thinking.
Adapted From: The memory for intermediate results that must be held during thinking.
Citation: working memory. (n.d.). WordNet® 2.0. Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=working memory&x=0&y=0

Definition: The memory that consists of information stored and retrieved explicitly from the external world. This information is about a specific event that has occurred at a specific time and place.  Associations are done with previously related stimuli or experiences in the formation, storage and subsequent retrieval of these memories.
Adapted From: Consists of information stored and retrieved explicitly from the external world. This information is about a specific event that has occurred at a specific time and place.  Associations are done with previously related stimuli or experiences in the formation, storage and subsequent retrieval of these memories.
Citation: explicit memory. (n.d.). Wikipedia. Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Wikipedia.org website: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explicit_memory

Definition: The long-term memory of skills and procedures
Adapted From: is often not easily verbalized, but can be used without consciously thinking about it.
Citation: The long-term memory of skills and procedures
column5: is often not easily verbalized, but can be used without consciously thinking about it.
column6: implicit memory. (n.d.). Wikipedia. Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Wikipedia.org website: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Implicit_memory

Definition: The mental faculty associated with the art of sound in time that expresses ideas and emotions in significant forms through the elements of rhythm, melody, harmony, and color.
Adapted From: An art of sound in time that expresses ideas and emotions in significant forms through the elements of rhythm, melody, harmony, and color.
Citation: music. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=music&x=0&y=0

Definition: The mental faculty of forming conclusions, judgments, or inferences from facts or premises.
Adapted From: The process of forming conclusions, judgments, or inferences from facts or premises.
Citation: reasoning. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=reasoning&x=0&y=0

Definition: The mental faculty associated with knowledge of one's body.
The mental faculty associated with awareness of the three-dimensional expanse in which all material objects are located and all events occur.
Adapted From: The unlimited or incalculably great three-dimensional realm or expanse in which all material objects are located and all events occur.
Citation: space. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=space&x=0&y=0

Definition: The mental faculty associated with the system of sequential relations that any event has to any other as past, present, or future.
Adapted From: The system of those sequential relations that any event has to any other, as past, present, or future
Citation: indefinite and continuous duration regarded as that in which events succeed one another.
column5: time. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=time&x=0&y=0

Definition: The mental faculty of experiencing an affective state of consciousness such as joy, sorrow, fear, hate, etc.
Adapted From: An affective state of consciousness in which joy, sorrow, fear, hate, or the like, is experienced, as distinguished from cognitive and volitional states of consciousness.
Citation: emotion. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=emotion&x=0&y=0

Definition: An emotion characterized by distress or uneasiness of mind caused by fear of danger or misfortune.
Adapted From: Distress or uneasiness of mind caused by fear of danger or misfortune.
Citation: anxiety. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=anxiety&x=0&y=0

Definition: An emotion characterized by a strong distaste, nausea, or loathing.
Adapted From: A strong distaste
Citation: nausea
column6: disgust. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=disgust&x=0&y=0

Definition: An emotion of being afraid aroused by distress, impending danger, evil, pain, etc.
Adapted From: A distressing emotion aroused by impending danger, evil, pain, etc., whether the threat is real or imagined

column5: fear. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=fear&x=0&y=0

Definition: An emotion of well-being ranging from contentment to intense joy.
Adapted From: A state of well-being characterized by emotions ranging from contentment to intense joy.
Citation: happiness. (n.d.). WordNet® 2.0. Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=happiness&x=0&y=0

Definition: An emotion of characterized by a comic, absurd, or incongruous quality causing amusement.
Adapted From: A comic, absurd, or incongruous quality causing amusement.
Citation: humor. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.1). Retrieved April 02, 2007, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/humor

Definition: An emotion of sorrow or mourning characterized by unhappiness or grief.
Adapted From: Affected by unhappiness or grief
Citation: sorrowful or mournful.
column5: sadness. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved October 02, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/sadness

Definition: An emotion of wrath or ire characterized by displeasure and belligerence aroused by a wrong.
Adapted From: A strong feeling of displeasure and belligerence aroused by a wrong
Citation: wrath
column6: anger. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=anger&x=0&y=0

Definition: The mental faculty of apprehending knowledge by means of the senses.
Adapted From: The act or faculty of apprehending by means of the senses.

Definition: The sense of hearing.
Adapted From: The sense, ability, or power of hearing.

Definition: The sense of tasting.
Adapted From: The act or faculty of tasting.

Definition: The sense of smelling.
Adapted From: The act or process of smelling.

Definition: The sense of bodily perception.
Adapted From: The faculty of bodily perception

column6: somesthesis. (n.d.). WordNet® 2.0. Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=somesthesis&x=0&y=0

Citation: pain. (n.d.). The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, Fourth Edition. Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=pain&x=0&y=0

Definition: The sense of sight.

column6: color. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=color&x=0&y=0

Adapted From: The action or process of moving or of changing place or position

column5: motion. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=motion&x=0&y=0

Definition: The visual perception of the quality of a distinct object in having an external surface or outline of specific form or figure.
Adapted From: The quality of a distinct object or body in having an external surface or outline of specific form or figure.
Citation: shape. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=shape&x=0&y=0

Definition: The mental faculty associated with sensitivity to stimuli originating inside of the body.
Adapted From: Sensitivity to stimuli originating inside of the body.
Citation: interoception. (n.d.). WordNet® 2.0. Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=interoception&x=0&y=0

Definition: The need for respiration.
Adapted From: Deep, rapid, and labored breathing caused by an increased respiratory drive due to abnormally low blood oxygen levels, as in severe heart failure or asthma.
Citation: air hunger. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?r=2&q=air hunger

Definition: The need to regulate blood pressure.
The need to eliminate urine.
The need for food.
Adapted From: A compelling need or desire for food.
Citation: hunger. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=hunger&x=0&y=0

Definition: The need for the body's cells to maintain fluid and electrolyte balance with their surroundings.
Adapted From: The process by which cells and simple organisms maintain fluid and electrolyte balance with their surroundings.

Definition: The need for sexual activity.
Adapted From: Concern with or interest in sexual activity.
Citation: sexuality. (n.d.). The American Heritage® Stedman's Medical Dictionary. Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=sexuality&x=0&y=0

Citation: cease being awake.
column5: sleep. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=sleep&x=0&y=0

Definition: The need for the maintenance of a constant internal body temperature independent of the environmental temperature.
Adapted From: Maintenance of a constant internal body temperature independent of the environmental temperature.
Citation: thermoregulation. (n.d.). The American Heritage® Stedman's Medical Dictionary. Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=thermoregulation&x=0&y=0

Definition: The need for liquid that causes a sensation of dryness in the mouth and throat.
Adapted From: A sensation of dryness in the mouth and throat caused by need of liquid.

Definition: The mental faculty associated with overt movements of the body.
Adapted From: The state or process of acting or doing.

Definition: The state or process of executing an overt movement of the body.
The state or process of overtly speaking.
Adapted From: The faculty or act of speaking.

Definition: The state or process of imagining an overt movement of the body.

Definition: The science of dealing with the effect of drugs.

Definition: The science of dealing with the effect of alcohol, a colorless, volatile flammable liquid synthesized or obtained by fermentation of sugars and starches and widely used, either pure or denatured, as a solvent and in drugs.
Adapted From: A colorless, volatile, flammable liquid synthesized or obtained by fermentation of sugars and starches and widely used, either pure or denatured, as a solvent and in drugs.
Citation: alcohol. (n.d.). The American Heritage® Stedman's Medical Dictionary. Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=alcohol&x=0&y=0

Definition: The science of dealing with the effect of a colorless or white crystalline alkaloid extracted from coca leaves, sometimes used as a local anesthetic especially for the eyes, nose, or throat and widely used as an illicit drug for its euphoric and stimulating effects.
Adapted From: A colorless or white crystalline alkaloid extracted from coca leaves, sometimes used as a local anesthetic especially for the eyes, nose, or throat and widely used as an illicit drug for its euphoric and stimulating effects.

Definition: The science of dealing with the effect of the dried leaves and female flowers of the hemp plant, used in cigarette form as a narcotic or hallucinogen.

Citation: marijuana. (n.d.). Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.0.1). Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=marijuana&x=0&y=0

Definition: The science of dealing with the effect of a central nervous system stimulant, C10H15N, used clinically in the treatment of narcolepsy, hyperkinesia, and for blood pressure maintenance in hypotensive states: also widely used as an illicit drug.
Adapted From: A central nervous system stimulant, C10H15N, used clinically in the treatment of narcolepsy, hyperkinesia, and for blood pressure maintenance in hypotensive states: also widely used as an illicit drug.

Definition: The science of dealing with the effect of a colorless, poisonous alkaloid, C10H14N2, derived from the tobacco plant and used as an insecticide. It is the substance in tobacco to which smokers can become addicted.
Adapted From: A colorless, poisonous alkaloid, C10H14N2, derived from the tobacco plant and used as an insecticide. It is the substance in tobacco to which smokers can become addicted.
Citation: nicotine. (n.d.). The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, Fourth Edition. Retrieved September 08, 2006, from Dictionary.com website: http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=nicotine&x=0&y=0
